Situation1: Laundry needs to be done so clean clothes are available for the family’s activities.
Situation2: A patient has arrived at the emergency room with a severe, fast-spreading infection that requires an immediate and powerful antibiotic treatment.
Story: I was folding the last of the towels when my phone buzzed urgently. My partner called from the kitchen, “Can you start the laundry? The kids need uniforms for tomorrow.” I nodded, feeling the weight of the day pressing on my shoulders. Just as I reached for the laundry basket, my hospital pager shrieked. A patient had just arrived in the ER—severe infection, time critical. I could picture the anxious faces of the nurses, the patient’s life hanging in the balance, waiting for my decision on the right antibiotic. My partner’s voice floated in from the other room, “Don’t forget the delicates, please!” I stood frozen, the laundry basket in my hands, my mind racing between the urgent needs at home and the life-or-death responsibility at the hospital. Both worlds demanded all of me, right now. My heart pounded as I tried to breathe, torn between the promise I made to my family and the oath I took as a doctor.
